text: hardly the usual suspects a combined age
of 278 when others would be enjoying
retirement these four men were plotting
a daring heist
Brian Reda was one the others called the
master the oldest he even used a free
bus pass to get to Hatton Garden the
CCTV placed him at the scene
disguised as a workman and reader came
with experience
Brian reader appeared in the dark
handcuffed two plainclothes police
officers decades earlier
the notorious 26 million pound Brinks
mat robbery from a warehouse at Heathrow
then in his mid-40s he was sentenced to
eight years in jail for handling stolen
gold bullion
Terry Perkins celebrated his 67th
birthday during the burglary here on
CCTV pushing a wheelie bin full of
stolen jewels a diabetic he brought his
medication in with him he said without
it he would have been the one taken out
in a bin he too had a criminal past
sentenced to 22 years for his part in
the six million pound raid on the
security express headquarters in East
London
the detective who helped convict him is
astonished at his latest crime I was
absolutely flabbergasted because some I
would have thought he would have learned
a lesson and retired and got on with his
property letting but obviously he
decided to have one more go for his
pension 74 year-old Kenny Collins was
the lookout on the night of the burglary
although some of the group claimed he
fell asleep during his lookout duties he
was filmed the morning after walking
away from the scene smartly dressed
briefcase in hand he'd also helped plan
the heist and the aftermath an often
brought his dog dempsey with him Danny
Jones was described in court as the
eccentric a Walter Mitty character who
liked to wear a fez and his mother's
dressing gown to bed he admitted that
he'd hidden some of the stolen jewelry
beneath family memorial stones at a
North London
a tree the police found far more than
he'd revealed as 60 years old he was the
youngest of the four here on a
walkie-talkie outside the vault
appearing to coordinate events and he
too had a history of burglary the raid
here at Hatton Garden over the Easter
weekend was bold but flawed what would
make a group of pensioners even with
their criminal past take such an
enormous risk this kind of criminal
enterprise gives them excitement makes
them feel alive takes them out of the
banality of the ordinariness of that
everyday lives it's that dream
aspirational job that everybody in this
kind of world that kind of underworld
dreams about even at their age they just
couldn't resist but their final crime
was too ambitious they were too naive
this group of unusual suspects now face
spending their twilight years in jail
Daniella Ralph BBC News Hatton Garden
